case_vignette: A 19-year-old female college student comes to the physician for a sudden loss of visual acuity of her right eye. She noticed that she was unable to read the time on the alarm clock when she woke up in the morning. When she closes her right eye, she is able to see sharply. When she closes her left eye, she has blurry double vision. She does not recall trauma to her eye but has been working long nights on her honors thesis. She has a history of occasional shoulder luxation. She is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall, and weighs 62 kg (136 lbs); her BMI is 19.1 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, slender and long fingers are noted. She has several flat, demarcated brownish nevi on her left cheek. Ocular examination shows upward temporal subluxation of her right lens.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've suddenly started having trouble with the vision in my right eye; it's all blurry, and I see double when I close my left eye.
Great, thank you for letting me know. Can you tell me how long have you been experiencing this symptom? And have you noticed any other changes in your vision recently?
I just noticed it this morning when I couldn't read the time on my alarm clock with my right eye.

Okay, thank you. Have you had any recent changes in your lifestyle or environment that could be related to the blurry vision in your right eye? For example, have you started a new job or moved to a new home? Have you experienced any changes in your diet or exercise routine?

Great, that's helpful information. Have you noticed any other symptoms apart from blurry vision in your right eye? For example, have you experienced headaches, dizziness, or eye strain? And have you had any previous eye problems or injuries?
No, I haven't had headaches, dizziness, or eye strain, and I don't recall having any eye injuries, but I do have a history of my shoulder coming out of place sometimes.

Okay, thank you for letting me know. Based on what you've told me, it's possible that your blurry vision in your right eye could be related to a muscle imbalance or injury in your neck, which is causing your eye to deviate or drift. This is a common condition known as a "strabismus."

Can you tell me more about your shoulder problems? How often do you experience shoulder instability, and do you have any pain or discomfort in your shoulder or neck?
I experience shoulder instability occasionally, but I don't have any pain or discomfort in my shoulder or neck right now.

Great, thank you for letting me know. Based on what you've told me, it's possible that your blurry vision in your right eye could be related to a muscle imbalance or weakness in your neck and shoulder muscles, which is causing your eye to deviate or drift. This can be treated with eye exercises and physical therapy to strengthen the muscles in your neck and shoulder.

Here are some exercises you can try at home to help improve your eye alignment:

1. Look straight ahead and gently rotate your head from side to side, keeping your eyes fixed on a point in front of you.
2. Hold a small object, such as a pencil, in front of you and focus on it with your right eye only. Then, switch to focusing on the object with your left eye only.
3. Place your finger in front of your face and look at it with your right eye only. Then, switch to looking at it with your left eye only.

Remember to do these exercises regularly, ideally once or twice a day, to help improve your eye alignment. If you experience any changes
